item.title: Am I stupid?
item.dc:creator: @Your_Grandpa Your Grandpa
item.description:
@Your_Grandpa wrote:

[code]#include
#include
#include
#include

using namespace std;

int Quantity, Cost, Total;
bool more;
string Name, More, Price, FileName;

int cents(string price) {
for(int i = 0 ; i < price.length(); i++)
if(price[i] == ‘.’)
price[i] = ’ ';
istringstream temp (price);
int dollars = 0, cents = 0;
temp >> dollars >> cents;
return 100 * dollars + cents;
};

int main () {
while(true) {
system(“cls”);
Total = 0;
do {
cout << "Please enter the name of the item (One word): ";
cin >> Name;
cout << “Item is called '” << Name << “’.” << endl << endl;
cout << "Please enter the cost of the item: ";
cin >> Price;
cout << “Item costs $” << Price << endl << endl;
cout << “How many of that item: “;
cin >> Quantity;
cout << Quantity << " of '” << Name << “’” << endl << endl;
Cost = Quantity * cents(Price);
Total += Cost;
FileName = Name + “.txt”;
ofstream a_file (&FileName[0], ios::app);
a_file << Name << " " << Quantity << " * $” << Price << endl;
a_file.close();
cout << “The current cost is $” << (Total / 100) << “.” << (Total % 100) << endl;
cout << "Are there any more items? ";
cin >> More;
more = More[0] == ‘y’ || More[0] == ‘Y’;
if(more)
cout << endl;
} while(more);
cout << “The total will be: $” << (Total / 100) << “.” << (Total % 100) << endl << endl;
system(“pause”);
};
return 0;
};

[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Am I stupid?
item.dc:creator: @RegeX RegeX
item.description:
@RegeX wrote:

Well, I’ve never done C++ but I’ll have a go :p.
At the top of your app you have:

#include <iostream>

etc.
We need to get another (api?) that is called fstream:

    #include <fstream.h>

And here is the tutorial http://www.cprogramming.com/tutorial/lesson10.html

Basically it creates a file pointer, writes to it, closes it, opens it, reads a token, waits for a keypress, and then the program destroys itself, along with the open file pointer.

Read full topic

item.title: Am I stupid?
item.dc:creator: @Zach1188 Zach1188
item.description:
@Zach1188 wrote:

Ok, thanks. I was used to VB where the default value is 0. Now one more question and I’ll be done with this thread (at leaste for now). How do I create a text file? I am actually making this program for my mom, she owns a bird store. She sells bird cages, bird seed, birds, bird toys etc. I want it to create a text file for each item sold. For example, the first question the program asks (before asking the price), is what is the items name (lets say we named it “BirdToy”). Then, when you finished entering all the details, I want it to create a file called “BirdToy.txt”, and within that file, I want it to have details for the item. For example, total money made on item, total tax paid for item, amount of item sold, etc. So how would I write the text file? I searched google but didn’t have much luck.

Read full topic

item.title: Am I stupid?
item.dc:creator: @RegeX RegeX
item.description:
@RegeX wrote:

[code]G:>g++ -o money money.c && money
Please enter the cost of the item: 2
Item costs $2

How many of that item: 5
5 of that item.

Current cost is $10, Are there more items (subtotal $10) (y/n)y

Please enter the cost of the item: 2
Item costs $2

How many of that item: 5
5 of that item.

Current cost is $10, Are there more items (subtotal $20) (y/n)n
The total will be: $20.
sh: PAUSE: command not found

G:>[/code][code]#include
#include
#include
using namespace std;

int main ()
{
int Price,Cost,Cost2 = 0; // These were your mistakes
int Quantity,Total = 0; // Didn’t give the values 0
string More(“y”);
while (More == “y” or More == “Y”)
{
cout << "Please enter the cost of the item: “;
cin >> Price;
cout << " Item costs $” << Price << “\n”;
cout << “\n”;
cout << "How many of that item: “;
cin >> Quantity;
cout << Quantity << " of that item.\n”;
cout << “\n”;
Cost = Quantity * Price;
cout << “Current cost is $” << Cost << “, Are there more items (subtotal $” << (Cost2 + Cost) << “) (y/n)”;
cin >> More;
Cost2 += Cost;
if (More == “y” or More == “Y”)
{
cout << “\n”;
}
}
cout << “The total will be: $” << Cost2 << “. \n”;
system(“PAUSE”);
return 0;

}[/code]

The reason you need to initialise the values is because when you create them, they are allocated addresses at &Count etc, but the actual value of the vars points to whatever was in memory before this var was allocated, hence you need to overwrite the 32 bits in memory to your new value for safety.
(I had to ask pd for the explanation, but I fixed the problem myself! Must count for something! :p)

Read full topic

Edit: I started a new program, and it’s not working right. I don’t understand why, heres the code:

// stringstreams #include #include #include using namespace std;

int main ()
{
int Price,Cost,Cost2;
int Quantity,Total;
string More(“y”);
while (More == “y” or More == “Y”)
{

      cout << "Please enter the cost of the item: ";
      cin >> Price;
      cout << " Item costs $" << Price << "\n";
      cout << "\n";
      cout << "How many of that item: ";
      cin >> Quantity;
      cout << Quantity << " of that item.\n";
      cout << "\n";
      Cost = Quantity * Price;
      cout << "Current cost is $" << Cost << ", Are there more items (y/n)";
      cin >> More;
      Cost2 = Cost2 + Cost;
      if (More == "y" or More == "Y")
      {
               cout << "\n";
      }
      
      

}    
cout << "The total will be: $" << Cost2 << ". \n";








system("PAUSE");
return 0;

}


It keeps bringing up weird results for the total, and I’m pretty sure I did it right.

item.title: Am I stupid?
item.dc:creator: @suck_my_r2h suck my r2h
item.description:
@suck_my_r2h wrote:

nade:

To complicate things I always got used to using things such as getch() to pause the program until the user hits a key, and VC++ doesn’t allow that.

You don’t need to use getch() in VC++. Whenever you execute a console application in VC++ it will add “Press any key to continue” to the output and wait for you to press a key before closing.

Read full topic

item.title: Am I stupid?
item.dc:creator: @nade nade
item.description:
@nade wrote:

Hmm, I can't afford Visual C++, and I don't feel like downloading a torrent of it. I have heard a lot of good things about Bloodshed. Does that mean I shouldn't use it at all?
That is the exact opposite of what I am saying, every compiler has it's own disadvantiges and advantiges, my school taught me with really old borland c++ compiler in dos - it was horrible I had to hit like 5 different keys to copy some text. To complicate things I always got used to using things such as getch() to pause the program until the user hits a key, and VC++ doesn't allow that.

Meh. Anyways, I am sure there is a way to fix that in Bloodshed C++ I just never used it - just mentioned a common error of people opening thier simple hello world applications and not seeing everything
